Working Pattern: Flexible working, Full-time, Job share, Part-time
Job Summary: The Employment Rights Directorate (ERD) sits in the Competition, Markets and Regulatory Reform Group at the heart of the Department for Business and Trade. Employment Rights is a top priority for the new Government who have set out an ambitious, wide ranging and long-term reform plan for workers’ rights in The Plan to Make Work Pay. The work is fast paced and high profile but, most importantly, has a significant tangible real-world impact on the lives of working people. To accommodate this new priority the Directorate has expanded significantly but retains a working culture that we are exceptionally proud of. We pride ourselves on the high quality and significant quantity of work that we deliver but we are clear that it is our working culture that enables us to deliver that. The Directorate is inclusive, friendly, collaborative, supportive and embraces genuinely flexible working.
Job Description: The National Minimum Wage & Wage Policy team in the Employment Rights Directorate has recently expanded to take on an exciting new remit to address a number of cross-cutting issues in wage policy. The team will design and implement a range of projects that will address existing and emerging issues to ensure workers are fairly compensated for their work. The work may include, but is not limited to, any of the following: Reviewing the interaction of national minimum wage, worker status and active working time Reforming the apprentice rate of the national minimum wage Delivering the national minimum wage uprating process Relationship management and sponsorship of the Low Pay Commission Reviewing and reforming payslip requirements to ensure fair wages Scoping opportunities to reduce the gender pay gap The Employment Status team is recruiting to support work on the government's commitment to simplify and improve the employment status framework. Employment status is a fundamental pillar of employment law and this role will involve a high level of complex policy development and analysis, looking at how the current framework works for both workers and employers and considering options for reform. The work may include, but is not limited to, any of the following: Supporting analytical research into how worker status is utilised in the labour market; Supporting the development of options to improve the employment status framework, and preparing consultation documents; Engaging cross-government and externally to identify opportunities to tackle bogus self-employment; Leading on the drafting of correspondence, responses to parliamentary questions, and briefing requests where these relate to directly employed workers; Engaging with legal colleagues to stay abreast of developments in case law relating to employment status.
Person Specification: Essential criteria The below criteria are essential and will be assessed at application stage. This role would generally suit someone who has: • Great problem-solving skills • Excellent written and oral communication skills • Ability to work collaboratively with your team and other government departments Desirable criteria The below criteria are desirable only. These will not be assessed throughout the recruitment process, but will be used in the event of tied scores between candidates. • Experience of working successfully with external stakeholders Behaviours • Making Effective Decisions (lead behaviour) • Communicating and Influencing • Working together • Seeing the Big Picture
Behaviours: We'll assess you against these behaviours during the selection process: Making Effective Decisions Communicating and Influencing Working Together Seeing the Big Picture We only ask for evidence of these behaviours on your application form: Making Effective Decisions
Selection Process: This vacancy is using Success Profiles (opens in a new window), and will assess your Behaviours and Experience.

Working Pattern: Flexible working, Full-time, Job share, Part-time
Job Summary: As a specialist prosecutor within counter terrorism division you review cases, make charging decisions and where appropriate prosecute cases, in accordance with the code for crown prosecutors, in relation to matters relating to national security and actions of the state- principally terrorism, core international crimes (war crimes, crimes against humanity, genocide and torture), state threats (National Security Act and Official Secrets Act offences), hijacking, piracy and inciting hatred. You advise on and prepare cases for prosecution, undertaking a personal caseload of complex criminal cases, requiring the marshalling of large quantities of evidence and unused material which needs to be formulated into cogent and manageable prosecution and disclosure strategies, using highly developed legal skills. You will be required to consider cases fairly in accordance with the code assessing the risks posed to victims and the public. You will conduct advocacy in the Magistrates Court and, if appropriately qualified, suitable hearings in the crown court. We currently have 4 roles available, although we anticipate this will increase shortly. The Crown Prosecution Service is based in England and Wales. If you’re applying for this role and live in Scotland or Northern Ireland, you must let us know when accepting this offer as you need permission to work from your home address if hybrid working is part of your role. There’s no guarantee that we will grant this approval.
Job Description: Your roles and responsibilities: You analyse and review evidence engaging with the police and other agencies, including investigators and prosecutors from foreign jurisdictions to determine who to charge, the appropriate charges and number of trials needed. You provide advice to police and other investigatory bodies, as well as to CPS Areas and Divisions, at the commencement of operations, pre-charge and post arrest, often involving large quantities of material, taking on board issues regarding evidential requirements, jurisdiction, admissibility of evidence, disclosure, unused material and custody time limits. You deal effectively and persuasively with a wide range of people, both internally and externally, as part of a multi-skilled team or individually in order to ensure the effective and successful prosecution of cases. Ensure that best practice is captured and share findings from debriefings with colleagues to improve the quality of the division’s casework and overall performance. You demonstrate a high level of oral and written communication skills in all matters relating to the prosecution of serious, complex or sensitive cases; in particular the ability to distil and explain legal complexities and decisions in nonlegal language. This will include drafting complex documentation and briefings as the need arises, including Prosecution Strategy and Disclosure Management Documents and applications for consent of the Law Officers. For all cases, especially Very High Cost Cases (VHCC), you prepare case plans, allocate counsel hours, monitor counsel hours against plan. Provide updates to line manager and take necessary remedial action to maintain costs within budget and ensure that cases are progressed to agreed timescales. A copy of the full job description is available if requested from Sophie.Cosgrove@cps.gov.uk
Person Specification: To be eligible to apply, you need to: be 18 years old or over have substantive experience of the Criminal Justice System, prosecuting or defending, including dealing with complex disclosure issues. you must be able to conduct court advocacy in the magistrates’ court. The post holder must be a qualified practicing solicitor or barrister, possessing a law degree or Common Professional Examination, having completed a Legal Practice course or the Bar Vocational course and the relevant pupillage. Whilst knowledge of the law and procedures relating to terrorism, national security and core international crimes, or aspects of these, would be of benefit, it is not an eligibility requirement, and a full induction will be provided, alongside a mentor, and ongoing training.
Qualifications: Legally qualified: You must be a qualified practising solicitor or barrister holding a valid Practising Certificate for England and Wales. Academic: You must have a law degree, Common Professional Examination and/or Graduate Diploma in Law. Professional: You must have completed a Legal Practice Course, Solicitors Qualifying Exam or Bar Professional Training Course and the relevant pupillage and training contract – or have received full exemption from the relevant professional regulatory body, either the Solicitors Regulation Authority or the Bar Standards Board. or CILEx: You must be a Fellow of CILEx and a CILEx Advocate/Litigator holding all three advocacy certificates providing you with a ‘general qualification’ within the meaning of s.71 (3) (c) Courts and Legal Services Act 1990. You must have a right of audience in relation to any class of proceedings in any part of the Senior Courts, or all proceedings in county courts or magistrates' courts in order to meet the requirements for a Crown Prosecutor specified by section 1 Prosecution of Offences Act 1985. If you don’t hold this CILEx qualification, you’re not eligible to apply for this vacancy. If you’re unsure whether you have qualified through CILEx, contact us to establish your eligibility for this role. If you apply and are found not to possess any of the above, any offer of employment will be withdrawn, or contract terminated. Equivalent qualifications won’t be accepted. If you’re unsure about your eligibility please contact Sophie.Cosgrove@cps.gov.uk
Behaviours: We'll assess you against these behaviours during the selection process: Making Effective Decisions Communicating and Influencing Seeing the Big Picture Delivering at Pace Working Together

Job Summary: * The Department will not consider sponsoring a visa or issuing a Certificate of Sponsorship. We are unable to offer advice on any Visa and Immigration cases. * The Department for Business and Trade (DBT) has a clear mission - to grow the economy. Our role is to help businesses invest, grow and export to create jobs and opportunities right across the country. The Departmental Security function’s role is to protect the DBT's people and assets from those who wish to damage it. We do this by building a diverse team with expert, generalist, and entry level roles to work together to solve the challenges we face. This mix allows us to develop talent and to benefit from a wide range of life experiences. This role sits within the Departmental Security's Information Assurance (IA) Hub. The IA Hub is a function providing stakeholders with a data-led view of DBT’s information risk exposure. It achieves this through securing the relevant data points from key control processes across DBT in combination with HMG and open-source intelligence to support in providing consumable reporting products to key stakeholders.
Job Description: This role will support the Head of the IA Hub with Key Risk Indicator (KRI) management. You will be a key link between the team and stakeholders in the wider department. The role entails: Supporting with risk identification and data analysis from a diverse range of qualitative information and quantitative data. Leading in behavioural insights for the IA Hub, keeping knowledge relevant in support of reporting products. Co-lead with business process analysis by identifying gaps in information security and assurance processes and support in implementing the appropriate processes to enable the function to carry out its responsibilities. Supporting the head of the function in identifying, securing and standardising all information assurance data points that are salient to stakeholder reporting. Supporting the IA Hub in producing the functions reporting products. Liaise where required to provide input, advice and guidance on information security. Support with the development, management and review of departmental security policies. Identify policy gaps and ensure alignment with other cross-cutting departmental policies. Supporting with security governance and working with stakeholders to manage risks associated with information assets. Supporting with mailbox enquiries and incident management. Providing ad hoc support to areas of the wider security team as and when required.
Person Specification: The below is a list of characteristics which may be helpful in this role. These will not be assessed throughout the recruitment process, but are laid out to help candidates understand more about the role. Personal attributes & skills Work flexibly with others and adapt to change. Able to work independently, prioritise and take initiative to effectively manage varied work strands and projects. Someone who is willing to make suggestions about how things can be improved when they see problems. Someone who can manage tight deadlines but is also able to push back when something is unrealistic. Essential criteria The below criteria are essential and will be assessed at application stage. This role would generally suit someone who has: A background and experience in risk data analysis. A good attention to detail, particularly in analysing and presenting information for internal and external audiences. The ability to work as part of a diverse team in a fast-paced environment. The ability to prioritise between multiple work streams to ensure that deadlines are met. SC cleared or be prepared to obtain SC before being appointed. Hold CISMP (or equivalent) or attain the qualification in the first 6 months when in post – this will be funded. Desirable criteria The below criteria are desirable only. These will not be assessed throughout the recruitment process, but will be used in the event of tied scores between candidates: Familiar with data management best practice. An understanding and experience of the security profession would be useful, though will be gained through exposure in the role. Good stakeholder engagement skills, with evidence of building effective working relationships with a wide range of stakeholders. Experience of working within or with government security. Basic knowledge of SQL, though can be learned when in post.

Job Summary: This role can be based in any of our office locations: London, Manchester, York, Bristol, Birmingham & Glasgow. If candidates wish to be based in a regional location, they will be expected to travel frequently to London for key meetings. Some occasional overseas travel may be required. We are looking for a truly exceptional and inspirational leader, who will role model corporate leadership, organisational values and cultural aspirations. Although there may be some changes to team structure and accountabilities over time, you'll be responsible for overseeing the delivery of our health and safety regulatory activities across GB’s non-mainline railways, leading a team of around 30 colleagues (including warranted inspectors). It covers Transport for London, circa 220 individual Heritage Railways, the seven main modern tram systems, and our high-gearing risk reduction role in securing Safety by Design. You will also lead our team of specialist Inspectors who provide expert support in a range of topic areas including civil engineering, electrical safety, occupational health, human factors, and digital safety. You'll be required to think strategically but will need to draw upon your experience of identifying and managing potential major accident and conventional health and safety risks to make important regulatory decisions to safeguard passengers, members of the public, and other users of the system. This is an SCS1 (Senior Civil Servant) post with a salary of up to £90,000 per annum. Please refer to the attached Candidate Information Pack for full details. Find out what our colleagues have to say about their ORR careers Our people , Office of Rail and Road (orr.gov.uk)
Job Description: The key responsibilities for the role are listed below: Provide inspiring and motivational leadership to ORR’s non-mainline railway teams, championing their work, directing and coordinating their efforts, and helping them to understand how their contribution supports the overall mission of ORR. Ensure that ORR’s plans for regulatory interventions are targeted on key risk priorities and lead to improvements that are sustained over time. Ensure that all of our regulatory work is delivered to the highest of standards and we make the right decisions, at the right time, to secure the right outcomes. You will also be responsible for driving forward improvements with our regulatory practice and associated processes. Ensure robust professional development for all colleagues within your team, knowledge retention and succession plans are in place for operational teams, to ensure continued success in delivering ORR’s existing and new initiatives. Play a leading role to support the delivery of the Chief Inspector's Regulatory Excellence Programme. As a member of the ORR Senior Leadership Group, you will take a lead role in helping to shape the development of the organisation and will be expected to contribute to relevant projects and initiatives This role can be based in any of our office locations: London, Manchester, York, Bristol, Birmingham & Glasgow. If candidates wish to be based in a regional location, they will be expected to travel frequently to London for key meetings. Some occasional overseas travel may be required.

Department: Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government
Working Pattern: Flexible working, Full-time, Job share, Part-time
Job Summary: Would you bring strong influencing skills and be comfortable in pushing back to your stakeholders when required? Are you proactive in seeking resolutions and can resolve issues that arise through innovative thinking? If so, we have an exciting opportunity for a Head of Enterprise Risk to join our team at the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government (MHCLG) and we'd love to hear from you! Here at the Ministry of Housing, Communities & Local Government (MHCLG), we work on things that make a real difference to people’s lives. Whether it's through the homes we live in, the work of our local councils, or the communities we’re all part of, our work is at the top of the political agenda. We have ambitious and far-reaching outcomes to achieve this year and, if you’re thinking of joining us, there’s never been a more exciting time. We are seeking an excellent candidate to lead Enterprise Risk Team at MHCLG. The role reports to the Deputy Director, Central Delivery Unit, that sits at the heart of MHCLG to proactively enable, support and improve delivery to achieve better outcomes for Ministers and citizens. The successful candidate will manage and develop a small team of cross-functional risk specialists and have a proven ability to design and apply risk management strategies, methodologies and policies and oversee their implementation in a large and complex organisation. The Head of Enterprise Risk supports the department’s executive and non-executive oversight bodies in embedding and maintaining the department’s Risk Management Framework. This role leads the Risk Management profession at MHCLG and drives continuous improvement activity to optimise risk management practices and associated changes. The Enterprise Risk Team acts as a custodian of the departmental Risk Management Framework, fulfils the 2nd line of defence responsibilities across all Principal Risk categories and oversees development and production of regular Risk Reporting for the Risk Sub-Committee, Executives, and the Board Risk Committee, thus supporting effective risk governance in the Department. We particularly welcome candidates from an ethnic minority background and other underrepresented groups to apply, as we work to continually improve our ability to represent the places and communities we support through our work.
Job Description: As the Head of Enterprise Risk your responsibilities will include: Lead the department’s risk strategy, including designing and implementing the Risk Maturity Plan and embedding a strong risk culture across the department. Develop, embed and maintain the Risk Management Framework and associated suite of risk policies and tools. Providing support and expertise in the monitoring and reporting on key risk indicators, assessment of risk classification and risk appetite compliance across the department and its ALBs. Serve as Head of Profession for Risk Management in MHCLG and influence the professional community in the wider government sector, including the activities of the Risk Centre of Excellence. Maintain the relationship with the product team for the department's delivery and risk reporting system, ensuring its configuration enables effective use of the risk-related tools and reporting across the department. Develop and oversee the production of regular risk reporting for Risk Sub-Committee, Executive Team and Audit and Risk Committee. Support the delivery and champion risk management capability within the organisation, including developing and presenting risk training material. Develop and nurture relationships with key internal and external stakeholders, advocating for a culture of effective risk management. Collaborate with Internal Audit and other assurance providers to support combined assurance and risk management. Coordinate the development of the departmental assurance map from the second and third line point of view.
Person Specification: The successful candidate will have: Strong knowledge and experience in risk management at a strategic level Confidence to engage with stakeholders in providing advice and/or constructive challenge. Strong written and verbal communication skills with a demonstrable track record of building credibility at all levels of an organisation, including senior leaders and external Board members Prior involvement in preparing reports for executives, risk committees and boards Deep understanding of risk and control frameworks Pragmatic approach to problem solving and strategically minded with a focus on department’s overall delivery objectives Ability to work seamlessly and intelligently across boundaries, collaborating with and drawing on resources from across MHCLG, Government and externally. Experience of influencing and realising change in government or a comparable large-scale complex organisation. Work experience in strategic finance or risk roles is welcomed given the department’s remit
Selection Process: As part of our pre-employment checking process, we will be using your CV to confirm your job history. Please note that by providing us with your CV you are consenting to us using the information enclosed as part of the checking process. CV and Cover Letter Declaration We recruit based on your knowledge and skills, and not background, gender or ethnicity - this is called name blind recruitment. Please remove references to your: name/title educational institutions age gender email address postal address phone number nationality/immigration status You will need to merge your CV and covering letter into one document. When submitting your application Applied will ask you to upload a CV, when doing this you should upload your merged document of your CV and covering letter. Most of our campaigns utilise multiple assessors and so it is possible that your application would be viewed by different assessors. At sift, through your CV and covering letter we will be assessing: Experience Technical In your CV, please set out your career history, highlighting specific responsibilities and achievements that are relevant for this role. Your covering letter should be no more than two pages and should provide examples of how your experience meets the essential criteria. The interview will be of a blended nature consisting of the following success profiles elements: Behaviour - Seeing The Big Picture, Working Together, Changing and Improving, Delivering at Pace Experience - Yes - Experience questions will be based around the essential skills and criteria as listed in the job description Strengths - The strength-based questions will require natural responses from the candidates. Candidates invited to interview will be expected to prepare presentation. Further details of the presentation will be sent along with invites to interview. The presentation will be assessed against Experience. In the full campaign we will test the below Success Profile Elements: Experience: Yes - Experience questions will be based around the essential skills and criteria as listed in the job description Technical: Yes – Technical questions will be based around the essential skills and criteria as listed in the job description. Strength: Yes - The strength-based questions will require natural responses from the candidates. Behaviours: Yes - Seeing The Big Picture, Working Together ,Changing and Improving , Delivering at Pace Please contact the vacancy manager if you have any questions about the role. We do not consider direct CV applications – you must apply for this role via the application link on Civil Service Jobs. Please note that near miss offers may be made at the lower grade to candidates who do not meet the grade criteria for this campaign. Grade 6 salary The salary for this role is £71,284 (London) or £64,679 (National). For existing civil servants, the usual policy on level transfer and promotion will apply and is non-negotiable. If you apply for a role that requires a transfer of location, for example if you are transferring from London to a National location, your salary will be adjusted in accordance with our policy on transfer between HQ pay ranges. Please note that the average employer pension contribution is based upon the National minimum salary for this role. Should your agreed starting salary for this role be different, the average employer pension contribution will be calculated accordingly. If you are a Secondee, this will not apply as you will remain on your home organisation’s terms and conditions. Benefits Transfers across the Civil Service on or after 4 October 2018: Any move to MHCLG from another employer will mean you can no longer access childcare vouchers. This includes moves between government departments. You may however be eligible for other government schemes, including Tax-Free Childcare. Determine your eligibility at https://www.childcarechoices.gov.uk. For further information about the benefits available to MHCLG employees, please see the attached Candidate Pack. Location Wolverhampton Darlington* Bristol Leeds Manchester London There may be opportunities for candidates to work flexibly depending on the business needs. This will be discussed with the vacancy manager on a case-by-case basis if you are successful for the role. *Please note: The Darlington Economic Campus is a pioneering new cross-government hub which will bring together people across departments and public organisations to play an active role in the most important economic issues of the day. The work of the Campus will make a real difference to people both across the UK and internationally. There will be substantial career opportunities and exciting prospects - a career at the Campus means you will be working at the heart of Government, with access to the benefits and fantastic opportunities offered by the civil service. For further information on the DEC, please take a look at the attached DEC candidate pack. At present, a minimum of 60% of your working time will be spent in your contractual office location. Requirements to attend other office locations or off-site meetings will be counted towards this. You will be asked to express a location preference during the application process. Sift and Interview dates Sifting is envisaged to take place starting 25/04/2025 with interview dates to be confirmed. All interviews are currently being held remotely via videocall. Reserve List In the event that we identify more appointable candidates than we currently have posts available, we will hold applicant details on a reserve list for a period of 6 months from which further appointments can be made. This may include roles at a lower grade. Candidates placed on a reserve list will be informed of this. Those candidates who do not wish to remain on the reserve list should contact recruitment@communities.gov.uk to be removed from the reserve list. CTC (Counter-terrorism Clearance): Important note Successful candidates for roles based in our 2 Marsham Street building must meet the security requirements before they can be appointed. The level of security needed is counter-terrorist check and the process can take up to 8 weeks to complete. Please note that successful candidates will need to pass the CTC security checks – this requires you to have been resident in the UK for the past 3 years. Please refer to the MHCLG Notes on Security Clearance section of our Candidate Pack for further information on Counter Terrorism Clearance (CTC). Candidates should also note that with effect from 1st August 2018 the department will also check all applicants who are successful at interview, against the Internal Fraud Database (IFD) held by the Cabinet Office. In accordance with the Civil Service Internal Fraud Policy, any applicant who is included on the IFD will be refused employment by MHCLG. Please see the Candidate Pack for further information on the Internal Fraud Database. Candidate Pack Information Please see attached Candidate pack for further information. Internal Fraud Database The Internal Fraud function of the Fraud, Error, Debt and Grants Function at the Cabinet Office processes details of civil servants who have been dismissed for committing internal fraud, or who would have been dismissed had they not resigned. The Cabinet Office receives the details from participating government organisations of civil servants who have been dismissed, or who would have been dismissed had they not resigned, for internal fraud. In instances such as this, civil servants are then banned for 5 years from further employment in the civil service. The Cabinet Office then processes this data and discloses a limited dataset back to MHCLG as a participating government organisations. MHCLG then carry out the pre employment checks so as to detect instances where known fraudsters are attempting to reapply for roles in the civil service. In this way, the policy is ensured and the repetition of internal fraud is prevented. For more information please see- Internal Fraud Register Feedback will only be provided if you attend an interview or assessment.

Role Type: Architecture and Data Defence Operations Digital Information Technology Intelligence
Job Summary: Do you want to work at the forefront of UK Defence, supporting specialist operations that are beyond the reach, capability, and expertise of other armed forces? The UK's military specialist units recruit the best of the armed forces and civilians to perform the most rewarding and complex tasks. We are recruiting exceptional individuals to support our activities tackling some of the most interesting and challenging national security issues in government. You will be working with unique, highly sensitive data, not seen elsewhere in defence, to the backdrop of a macro environment that is ever changing. Some of the challenges you will face include working in mixed military and civilian teams to enable high risk operations by providing timely, accurate and trustworthy data and the development of cutting-edge capabilities. This position is advertised at 37 hours per week.
Job Description: You will be supporting the delivery of data products and capabilities used on discreet military operations promoting the UK’s national interest across the globe. As our capabilities become ever more complex, consuming larger quantities of data, the effective, reliable, and scalable ability to process data into consumable products is essential. The team in London is a mix of civilian, military personnel and contracted support working in collaboration with other teams across locations in the UK and overseas. We work across security classifications and have direct access to the operational users need. We work closely with NATO, Five Eyes and other partners. There is opportunity for international travel to support operations within risk tolerance. Some of the responsibilities you will take on include: Implement and automate data flows to connect operational systems and data for analytics to exploitation systems. Write scripts to extract, transform and load (ETL) data for ingestion and structure/format data for export around other parts of the business. Develop and implement data engineering best practice (source-to-target mapping, code standards, data quality, generating representative datasets etc.) Support and mentor other data engineers as well as develop your own skills. Setup and administer global policies for data.
Person Specification: Essential Criteria NiFi, Airflow and Azure Data Factory Python and Pandas SQL/NoSQL Databases (Neo4j, Elastic, Azure Blob) Messaging technologies such as Kafka Storage solutions such as Min-io or Ceph Experience of agile working Kubernetes (AKS and Kubernetes Engine) DevSecOps best practices, including source control (Git) and vulnerability scanning Desirable Criteria AWS & Azure solutions for storage and data engineering, particularly tools available on Stack Hub Data analysis and visualisation tools such as Palantir, Tableau, PowerBi, TAK Familiarity with data governance and lineage practices

Technical Skills: We'll assess you against these technical skills during the selection process: Data development process Data integration design Programming and build (data engineering) Problem resolution (data)

Job Title: International Climate & Energy: Green Growth & Long-term Strategy Adviser
Department: Department for Energy Security & Net Zero
Working Pattern: Flexible working, Full-time, Job share, Part-time
Job Summary: Do you want a career where you can make a real difference? Do you want to work at the forefront of current policy making decisions? Do you want to have an impact on the UK and beyond? If yes, then a career at the Department for Energy Security and Net Zero (DESNZ) could be for you. Here at DESNZ we are delivering our mission to make the UK a clean energy superpower, with clean electricity by 2030 and accelerating the UK’s journey to net zero. Our work is helping ensure clean energy for all, keep bills down and seize the opportunities to lead the world in new green industries, taking back control of our energy with Great British Energy and encouraging greater energy efficiency across the UK. The work of the department has never been more timely or relevant, and by joining us you will be part of making that difference. Our work is varied, interesting and most importantly it's impactful. Our DESNZ Values are interwoven into everything we do; we are bold, we are collaborative, we are inclusive, and we learn. As a department we are committed to these values to build a culture where everyone can thrive We offer great working benefits including a world-class pension, flexible working options and a career where your learning and development is taken seriously. We are enormously proud to be a Disability Confident Leader employer. We support candidates with adjustments throughout our recruitment process. Information about disability confidence and just some examples of the adjustments that you can request can be found in the reasonable adjustment section below. The Civil Service is committed to attract, retain and invest in talent wherever it is found. To learn more please see the Civil Service People Plan and the Civil Service D&I Strategy. Find Out More We regularly run events where you can find out more about the department and tips for the application and interview process. You can sign up for upcoming events here: https://forms.office.com/e/pqUhdr3L72 You can also follow our LinkedIn Careers Page: https://www.linkedin.com/showcase/desnz-careers/
Job Description: Are you ready to be at the forefront of the global energy transition and international climate action? This is your chance to make a real impact by working at the heart of the government’s international net zero strategy. The energy transition is transforming the global economy, the impacts of climate change are increasingly apparent and the geopolitics are complex. We need analytical and bold thinkers to provide challenge and advance UK leadership, growth and resilience. About us: The International Climate & Energy Joint Strategy Unit is a dynamic and collaborative team in DESNZ’s International Net Zero directorate. We work closely with other government departments as well as with external stakeholders (including business, academia and civil society), to bring together the UK’s international climate, nature & energy strategy. Our team is passionate about our mission and dedicated to creating a supportive, inclusive environment. We fully embrace flexible working and equal opportunity. We take learning and development seriously, offering ample opportunities for growth given the breadth of our agenda. Your Role: As a key member of the Strategy Unit, you will be responsible for putting green growth at the centre of the UK’s international climate, nature and energy strategy. You will lead on identifying and assessing key economic and geopolitical trends, risks and opportunities to progress international net zero policy development at pace, solving complex problems under tight deadlines.
Person Specification: In this role you will: - Influence government on the interlinkages between the international climate, nature & energy, as well as wider HMG priorities on the growth mission. This will include supporting the development of a 2030 climate nature and energy strategy. - Lead new horizon scanning or systems thinking work with green growth at the centre, working proactively and collaborating with analysts to identify emerging trends and putting forward recommendations on how the government should respond. - Convene government and external working groups on green growth and an international net zero strategy to progress strategy at pace, as well representing International Net Zero interests in cross-department discussions on international climate, nature and energy strategy. - Support senior management and Ministers in vital decision making on the international net zero and green growth agenda, as well their broader engagements. Essential Criteria We would love to hear from you if you: - Have sound experience of assessing big picture trends, risks and opportunities and can identify priorities in a complex context, particularly geopolitical or economic trends. Experience in economic forecasting, or economic strategy development/implementation would be preferable. - Are a self-starter who can lead work independently on a day-to-day basis, managing your own delivery and delivering through others. - Are confident in their ability to manage novel horizon scanning or systems thinking projects and deliver quality outputs that support government decision making. - Can build relationships and networks with colleagues across the department, wider government and beyond. - Have strong attention to detail and good written and oral communication skills. - Can demonstrate flexibility to deliver at pace in a fast-changing and exciting environment. Desirable Criteria Having a broad understanding of international governance, net zero and climate security risks is desirable but not essential. We ask that candidates are prepared to spend a minimum of 18 months in the role.

Department: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs
Working Pattern: Flexible working, Full-time, Job share, Part-time
Job Summary: The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) is the UK government department responsible for safeguarding our natural environment, supporting our world-leading food and farming industry, and sustaining a thriving rural economy. Our broad remit means we play a major role in people's day-to-day life, from the food we eat, and the air we breathe, to the water we drink. The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) is the UK government department responsible for safeguarding our natural environment, supporting our world-leading food and farming industry, and sustaining a thriving rural economy. Our broad remit means we play a major role in people's day-to-day life, from the food we eat, and the air we breathe, to the water we drink. Defra is transforming the way it manages and exploits information and data. As part of this transformation, a new Chief Data Officer’s team is being established within the Science and Analysis Group, working in close collaboration with Digital and Data colleagues. The Library Officer role sits within the Chief Data Officer’s team and reports to the Library Services manager. The Chief Data Office offers an exciting opportunity for a Library officer. Defra library is part of the Government KIM (GKIM) professional community that works across departments, agencies, and arms’ length bodies (ALBs) to support and champion the creation, organisation and exploitation of information and knowledge. Defra library has committed to the Green Library Manifesto. Encouraging diverse applicants We recognise the challenges that people with (multiple) protected characteristics may experience on the job market and in their career progression. We are fully committed to being an inclusive employer and ensuring equal opportunities. We are keen to make our workforce as diverse as possible, and we hope to attract applications from underrepresented groups.
Job Description: Defra Library team provides library services and resources to support all staff in Defra, APHA, and Natural England in having the evidence base to perform their business functions. In addition, the library also provides these functions to the Joint Nature Conservation Committee (JNCC), Veterinary Medicines Directorate (VMD), Office for Environmental Protection (OEP) and a Document Delivery Service to the Marine Management Organisation (MMO). Defra Library plays a vital role in enabling our customers to base policy processes, research and decision making on the best possible evidence. The library provides a gateway to a wide range of high-quality information resources. We strive to provide an outstanding, sustainable service that adds real value by empowering colleagues to make the best possible use of the library resources and services.
Person Specification: Key responsibilities The responsibilities of the role include: Enquiry service: providing an enquiry service to library customers including undertaking literature searches, copyright advice and general enquiries; assisting with the management of the service including recording accurate service statistics. Document delivery: providing a document delivery service; assisting with the management of the service including recording accurate service statistics. Resource management: manage electronic resources access and user registration, liaising effectively with customers and suppliers; lead on renewal processes for assigned electronic resources, financial processes, and value for money exercises. Collection development: assist with collection development and management processes as required, e.g., library collection reviews. Cataloguing: contribute to cataloguing and classifying the physical and electronic library collection; supporting the Central Science Division with administering the publication of Defra research publications, to Science Search and other repository and research discovery systems. Communication and marketing: boost engagement through targeted marketing and engagement plans with an emphasis on accessibility and inclusivity; collaborate in the development and updating of the content of the library SharePoint Community pages. Other Duties: The post holder is required to work in a flexible way and undertake any other duties reasonably requested by line management which are commensurate with the grade and level of responsibility of this post. Skills and Experience Library services. You have experience of answering library enquiries, providing document delivery, and literature searches. Library systems. You have experience of working with resource discovery and cataloguing, library management systems, reference databases, and authentication platforms and can support user experience for these systems. Problem solving. You have experience in recognising problems and implementing creative solutions. You know how to anticipate and respond to problems at the right time. You understand how the problem fits into the bigger picture. Communication: You are confident in using a variety of communication tools and methods for use in marketing and customer engagement. You will have the communication skills to build strong relationships with people at all levels. Continuous improvement. You have a desire to explore new library and information trends and exploit continuous development and learning opportunities to contribute to the strategic development of Defra Library. Organisation. You are well organised, with good planning and delivery skills and with a professional approach that allows senior colleagues to trust your judgement. Degree or post-graduate qualification in Library and Information Studies, information management or another relevant subject or equivalent experience and commitment to complete a degree in librarianship. You will possess the relevant skills aligned with the Government Knowledge and Information Management (GKIM) Framework for the Librarian.

Job Summary: Why Join Us? By joining a communications team, you will become a member of Government Communications, a profession of around 6000 communicators working in a variety of government departments, agencies and arm’s length bodies. You’ll benefit from continuous professional development from our new learning and development curriculum, a network of skilled communicators sharing best practice, mentoring opportunities, and more! For more information on how becoming a part of the Communications Profession can support your career and development please visit our careers page. For our top tips on how to write your application, please take a look at our recruitment top tips for candidates guide.
Job Description: About the Government Communications Apprenticeship During this apprenticeship, you will spend 18 months working in one or more exciting communications teams within Government Communications. You will be placed within a government department, while studying for a Level 4 Public Relations and Communications Assistant qualification. You can find out more about the programme by visiting our GCS website. You'll have the opportunity to work across various communications disciplines and contribute to delivering cutting-edge work for the UK Government that reaches millions of citizens across the UK and abroad. For example, by: Developing innovative communication plans across multiple digital platforms, beyond traditional print and broadcast media Working collaboratively with colleagues across GCS organisations and sectors, using AI, digital and social media channels to reach different audiences Working on creative government campaigns to build public trust and encourage community participation Researching and analysing the needs of a variety of audiences through data & insight, or Organising key events and visits for stakeholders across the country and abroad. You will gain valuable experience across media, internal communications, digital, data & insight, external affairs, marketing or strategic communications. See more information on the Communications disciplines here. We are committed to Equality, Diversity and Inclusion and determined to ensure that the profession is representative of the audiences we are communicating with. We recognise that greater diversity enhances our work and we welcome applications from the widest range of people of different backgrounds, cultures, and experiences as well as those who have caring responsibilities.
Person Specification: Essential Criteria Successful candidates will be able to: Demonstrate an interest in news stories and have an understanding of current affairs and the work of Government Communications Have an understanding of digital and social media platforms Confidently use Microsoft Office applications such as Word and PowerPoint, with the ability to quickly adapt to new software Be flexible, proactive and able to work under-pressure to deadlines Demonstrate good interpersonal, written, presentation and verbal communication skills Be organised and creative and demonstrate the ability to work effectively with strong attention to detail Work effectively as part of a team, contributing to shared goals and fostering a positive team environment. Desired Criteria Ability to use a variety of creative communication tools and digital channels to deliver key messages e.g. creating and managing digital content on TikTok, Instagram, and YouTube Evaluate the impact and effectiveness of your work and communications delivery. Eligibility To apply, you must: Have 5 GCSEs at grades 4-9 (A*-C) or equivalent including English and Maths. Have the equivalent of 2 A-levels achieved by September 2025, preferably including a communications related subject, for example English Literature or English Language (but not essential). Not be in full-time education Not already hold a level 4 qualification, including a degree, in a communications-related field Have the right to live and work in the United Kingdom Not be enrolled on any other apprenticeship Have been living in the EEA, Switzerland, the UK or Gibraltar for at least the last 3 years before starting an apprenticeship

Job Title: Deputy Director of Traffic and Technology
Working Pattern: Flexible working, Full-time, Job share, Part-time
Job Summary: At the Department for Transport (DfT) we’re working to improve every kind of journey. We’re harnessing new technology to create safer, more sustainable transport. And, creating better connections between people and places, we’re enabling greater growth opportunities for communities UK-wide. It all means that here, you are part of something very different and special. DfT and our agencies employ around 15,000 staff, of whom about 3800 are in the core Department, and we have the largest and most complex capital project portfolio in Government, delivered principally through delivery partners including Network Rail, HS2 Ltd and National Highways. We are broadening our presence around the country and are growing new locations in Leeds and Birmingham. Our Secretary of State has set out her 5 strategic priorities, putting transport at the heart of mission-driven government. They include: improving performance on the railways and driving forward rail reform improving bus services and growing usage across the country transforming infrastructure to work for the whole country, promoting social mobility and tackling regional inequality delivering greener transport better integrating transport networks More information about DfT can be found on our website here Departmental Vision All DfT employees are guided by the Civil Service core values of honesty, integrity, impartiality and objectivity. Everything we do to achieve this is reinforced by our values: Confidence: to challenge, to take action, to innovate. Excellence: in our professionalism, in our delivery, in our learning. Teamwork: we are inclusive, we collaborate and we support each other.
Job Description: Deputy Director of Traffic and Technology is a varied and challenging role at the heart of reforming the way our roads work and addressing the issues that matter to everyday road users. This is a high profile role with a significant degree of Ministerial interest and a large multi-disciplinary team. The successful candidate will: Set the policy for how roads are used and regulated. This requires working with teams across the Road Transport Group, balancing competing demands for how road space should be used and priorities given for different modes. Lead a significant programme to digitise the way roads operate. This includes developing the new Digital Traffic Regulation Order (DTRO) system – a key step in preparing the road network for autonomous vehicles, providing better in-vehicle data to drivers and making more flexible use of the road – as well as running the existing Street Manager service to manage Street Works and Blue Badge digital service. Lead a significant legislative programme including elements of primary legislation in the Planning and Infrastructure Bills, as well as the potential for primary legislation on the long-standing issue of pavement parking. As well as a significant programme of secondary legislation to reform the way street works operate and lane rental schemes to tackle the perennial concern about utility works being disruptive and poorly coordinated. Oversee a suite of statutory and non-statutory guidance setting out to local authorities how they should manage their roads ranging from guidance on bus lanes to street design.
Person Specification: You will need to be able to show, through your application, that you have the professional skills, breadth of experience and personal qualities for this post, as well as the leadership skills to succeed at Deputy Director level in the Senior Civil Service. Outstanding leadership skills with the ability to recruit, inspire, empower and motivate the best staff; build genuinely diverse and inclusive teams; and grow capability and resilience to deliver outcomes even when working under scrutiny or at a high pace Excellent decision making with the ability to see the strategic connections between issues and recommend the right decisions in a political environment Highly developed communication skills enabling you to influence with senior stakeholders and to deliver complex information clearly and concisely A track record of driving delivery against demanding timescales, balancing resources over competing demands and proactively managing risks

Job Title: Engagement Strategy, Account Management and Excellence and Engagement Delivery Roles
Role Type: Business Management and Improvement Operational Delivery
Working Pattern: Flexible working, Full-time, Job share, Part-time
Job Summary: Business Engagement Unit: The Business Engagement Unit sits within the Advocacy Directorate of the Department for Business and Trade. We are a central team critical to the delivery of the Government’s Growth Mission, and the coordination of business engagement across Whitehall. The team is organised around the four functions which we deliver: engagement policy development; engagement strategy & coordination; delivery of Ministerial business engagement; and coordination of account management across Whitehall. We are a fast paced, diverse and trusting team, in which we all work closely together to deliver. Our inclusive, and high performing culture is very important to us. We are recruiting for three of the four G6 roles in the team: Strategy, Delivery, and Account Management. Engagement Strategy Team: The team is responsible for setting the strategic direction of the DBT’s overall business engagement, creating a long-term plan and translating this into clear quarterly deliverables for Ministers and Senior Officials. It also takes the central role in managing relationships with the key business representative organisations (B5) and coordinating engagement across Whitehall. The key priorities for this team are long term planning of engagement events to a two-year time horizon, compiling quarterly forward looks for Ministers and Senior Officials, and developing a refreshed strategy for engagement with the five BROs as well as the relaunched Board of Trade. Engagement Delivery Team: The team is responsible for the delivery of Ministerial engagement, in the form of roundtables, bilaterals and small-scale events (e.g. Ministerial broadcast calls to the business community). The team is also responsible for delivery of Board of Trade events and accompanying Board of Trade Advisers to external Board of Trade events. These portfolios closely working together and supporting each other as necessary. The team will liaise with Private Office, sectors and other relevant teams in DBT and across Whitehall to ensure that Ministerial events run smoothly and achieve their policy objectives. Account Management & Excellence Team: The Account Management & Excellence Team is responsible for maintaining and operating the cross-Whitehall Account Management Framework and driving excellence in the way that Business Engagement is undertaken across the Department and HMG. This involves taking a leading role across Government in sharing information, best practice and driving good behaviours in support for the growth mission.
Job Description: Engagement Strategy Team: The postholder will be responsible for overseeing the development of the two year engagement programme, along with designing a process to turn this into quarterly schedules for Ministers and senior officials. In addition, the postholder will lead the team to design and deliver the Board of Trade agenda, and regular engagement with the B5 group of Business Representative Organisations. Beyond this the successful candidate will be the strategy centre for engagement within Government, working closely with No.10, HM Treasury and a network of colleagues from other departments. Key deliverables include: Overseeing horizon scanning for emerging trends. Managing production of a 2 year forward look, ensuring seniors’ buy-in, and keeping it updated. Overseeing a strategic plan of events that supports future milestones (sectors, policies and initiatives). Leading deliver of a cross-DBT governance to make sure that the single engagement strategy aligns with the comms strategy and is responsive to changes in Departmental priorities and the external environment. Ad Hoc strategy and coordination for HMG priorities. Line Management of 3x direct reports and a team of 7. Engagement Delivery Team: The postholder will be responsible for leading the team to ensure smooth delivery of roundtables, broadcast calls and bilaterals for DBT Ministers. The postholder will work with teams across DBT to ensure roundtables & bilaterals have clear policy outcomes and deliverables, whilst also be involved in the planning and execution. This is a special role which will require significant specialist experience. This will require: Setting best practice on how to deliver business engagement (eg – setting out ways of working with teams involved in Ministerial engagement). Overseeing planning for the programme of bilaterals, roundtables, and wider engagements. Finding creative and innovative ways for DBT Ministers to engage with a wide range of businesses and stakeholders. Managing senior stakeholders such as Ministers and Senior Officials. Working closely with Private Offices and DBT teams to ensure Ministerial engagement runs smoothly, this includes co-ordinating the briefing, running the logistics, responsible for identifying & managing attendees. Line management responsibilities for 2x direct reports and an overall team of seven, supporting the team to deliver at pace and under pressure. Account Management & Excellence Team: The role would lead on: Overseeing developing and defining the business engagement framework for DBT and across Whitehall. Establishing governance structures and forums to operating and oversee the managing of Government relationships with Business. Building and maintaining relationships with business-facing teams within DBT and across Whitehall. Shaping the build of supporting IT systems. Line management of 3x direct reports and team of 7. The role is exciting, fast-paced and provides the opportunity for self-directed and driven work and leadership. It is particularly varied in needing the skills to design and establish a system in the early stages of the role, then transitioning to building relationships, operating and convening groups across Government to iterate, assure and improve the way we do things.
Person Specification: Essential Criteria The below criteria are essential and will be assessed at application stage; Ability to present and set direction with excellent written and verbal communication and drafting skills. Ability to collaborate widely, influence seniors and bring others with you with credibility. Exceptional leadership skills including a track record of team building and willingness to develop a positive culture with the rest of the team. Track record of communicating and influencing with senior stakeholders. Highly organised and able to build strong relationships with colleagues around DBT and Whitehall. Credibility at engaging with Ministers, Senior Officials and business leaders. Ability to work across organisational boundaries to deliver outcomes. Desirable Criteria The below criteria are desirable only. These will not be assessed throughout the recruitment process, but will be used in the event of tied scores between candidates; Experience of Account Management/Relationship Management practices. Familiarity with cross Whitehall ways of working & dynamics. Experience of business engagement, in particular strategic planning for engagement with large businesses. Existing relationships with No.10 and relevant Government departments. Job Summary: The post is in Department for Business and Trade (DBT), UK Defence & Security Exports (UKDSE) which provides support and guidance to UK based defence and security companies with their exporting objectives. The UKDSE Events Team is situated within the Operations Directorate and is comprised of both civilian and military personnel. The team’s work is a key part of UKDSE’s frontline delivery of maintaining strategic relationships through an ever-evolving programme of events and exhibitions across the world. It is a highly desirable post, ensuring maximum exposure for UKDSE and UK industry at defence and security trade exhibitions and events globally. It is a very high-profile role which is physically demanding, with tight schedules and challenging deadlines. The successful candidate will be responsible for co-ordinating key elements of UKDSE’s participation in major high-profile defence and security events which attract cross-Whitehall interest, including at Ministerial level. The post will work closely with a wide range of stakeholders across all levels including UKDSE’s Senior Management Team (SMT), Regional Desk Officers, Military personnel, contractors, UK industry, event organisers and international Ministerial and military delegations.
Job Description: UKDSE Events Project Manager responsibilities include: To project manage the build, delivery, and onsite management of UKDSE facilities at nominated UK and international exhibitions, in collaboration with the internal event sponsor. Establishing responsibility for key deliverables and ensuring all activities are carried out in accordance with project timelines. Ensuring events objectives are delivered within allocated budget, whilst identifying and mitigating against any risks. Completing all relevant documentation in accordance with departmental policy. Delegation manager at selected events/exhibitions; to manage UKDSE’s SMT, UK Ministers, UK Senior Military staff, international Ministerial and Military high level VIP delegations around UK company stands to ensure maximum exposure for UK industry. Day-to-day management of exhibition stand build contract and management and reporting activity for the marketing and promotional budget for UKDSE exhibitions. To develop and maintain relationships with UK industry, appointed contractors, and event organisers to maximise opportunities for UK industry attendance at exhibitions and events. To effectively manage the events requirements of a wide range of internal and external stakeholders for nominated UK and international exhibitions. To manage finance processes, working closely with organisers and trade associations to book the most advantageous space. Managing stand space payments to ensure all activity is in line with projected budgets. Managing invoicing of companies to ensure timely confirmation of attendance at events.
Person Specification: Essential Criteria The below criteria are essential and will be assessed at application stage; Project Management knowledge and proven experience of delivering events. Strong oral and written communication skills. Proven experience of working with contractors. Knowledge of the defence and security sectors. Proven experience of working with the Private Sector and SMEs. Proven experience of working with mixed teams of Military Personnel and Civil Servants. Must hold a project management qualification or equivalent training. Desirable Criteria The below criteria are desirable only. These will not be assessed throughout the recruitment process, but will be used in the event of tied scores between candidates; Strong communication skills, able to influence stakeholders and advocate effectively to and on behalf of senior officials. Able to see the big picture, supporting strategic decisions. Personal Attributes & Skills The below is a list of characteristics which may be helpful in this role. These will not be assessed throughout the recruitment process, but are laid out to help candidates understand more about the role. This role would generally suit someone who; The successful candidate would ideally be an enthusiastic team player who is capable of working independently both in the UK and overseas, but who knows when to refer to management when required They should have successful experience in delivering to a project brief on time and within cost parameters Comfortable in prioritising their work and working to tight and changeable deadlines They should be able to initiate and develop relationships with a wide range of internal and external stakeholders Whilst part time working and job share applicants would be considered, the roles require regular travel within the UK and overseas for periods of often up to 10 days Due to the nature of exhibition and event management which often requires long hours, and a certain degree of physical mobility and fitness is required.
Qualifications: Must hold a project management qualification or equivalent training.

Job Summary: About the Role Responsible for overseeing the data analytical function to deliver accurate and timely analytics that will inform strategic business decisions.
Job Description: What you will be doing: Responsible for the collation and manipulation of data in support of the SIA’s strategic priorities Compiling and delivering regular reports to executive level and to the board. Maintaining and ensuring the relevance of key performance metrics 1. Providing technical and analytical expertise to deliver high impact reporting Pro-actively seeking opportunities to leverage data to help inform business decisions Deliver data in the most appropriate way for the audience (inc PowerBI dashboards) 2. Delivering quality assured data across the organisation and beyond Ensuring outputs from the analysis team are fully quality assured and accurate Working with ICT and other partner teams to promote access to data and analytics, to help the SIA become a more data-driven organisation Working strategically across the organisation to ensure the analysis team are a trusted provider of accurate data 3.
